stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the level design and layout for Course 14, a large level with a cardboard diorama and crafts theme. The stream focused on blocking out platforming paths to avoid linearity, brainstorming and creating new on-theme assets like a paper mushroom, and diagnosing and solving performance issues on real N64 hardware.

development_findings.summary: The level design for Course 14 is inspired by the non-linear, open structure of games like Bowser's Fury, with multiple paths leading to different objectives.
development_findings.quote: This is very similar to the layout in peaches fury and that one was really not linear.

development_findings.summary: Kaze performs real-time performance analysis on N64 hardware using a Summer Cart, identifying that RDP overdraw is the primary bottleneck, not polygon count.
development_findings.quote: Yeah, you can see 18 milliseconds RSP. So the RSP could run this at like 50 FPS and the RDP is at 36.8. That means it's all the overdraw.

development_findings.summary: A new platform type, a mushroom made from a toilet paper roll and gift wrap, was conceived and created during the stream, demonstrating a creative process that draws inspiration from real-world crafts.
development_findings.quote: Dude, the toilet paper roll is too good. I can't not do this.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is actively optimizing the game's rendering engine at a low level, successfully saving 30 instructions by caching a value in a loop.
development_findings.quote: I found 30 instruction improvement in Graph Render again. Which is also fucking sick.

development_findings.summary: A user in chat suggested a code optimization to replace a variable with a pointer, which Kaze identified as a 'very good idea' that could save another 20 instructions, showing collaborative technical problem-solving.
The level is planned to have multiple distinct biomes made of cardboard, such as a grassland, a mountain area, and potentially a volcano or water area, to add environmental variety.
Kaze clarifies that the level being worked on, Course 14, is not the intro level, correcting a misconception.
development_findings.quote: This is the intro level, this is course 14.

development_findings.summary: Kaze created a challenging optional platforming section using crayon models, intended for skilled players to collect a Yoshi Coin.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that for the game's craft-based aesthetic to work, the materials must look realistic and behave as players would expect, which guides his detailed work on textures and shaders.
context_findings.quote: The materials need to look realistic to be convincing. Cause we all know wrap paper has a little bit of a shine to it. So if it doesn't have to shine, people might not identify it as a wrap paper.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is designing the game to be more difficult than the original Mario 64 and seems dismissive of potential complaints about it being too easy, suggesting a focus on challenging gameplay.
context_findings.quote: Do you guys actually think that people will complain that the game is too easy? I feel like that's an insane thing to complain about. I am not struggling enough. But this is already gonna be a lot harder than vanilla Mario 64.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shares a personal anecdote about enjoying his new automatic lawnmower, humorously framing it as a sign of 'becoming a boomer'.
context_findings.quote: I have become a boomer by the way. I installed an automatic lawnmower and I enjoy my lawnmower right now. That's fucked up isn't it?

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a personal design rule to not reference games or concepts that were released after the Nintendo 64's lifespan, maintaining a period-appropriate feel.
context_findings.quote: You know lava came on after my 64 things it was lifetime. So no reference to that. That's my rule.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions he is self-employed and takes on commissions if the price is high enough, indicating how he supports himself financially during development.

zeina.summary: Kaze designates Zeina, his spouse, as the 'chat mom' during the stream, though her direct contributions as an animator were not discussed.
zeina.quote: Zeina's gonna be the chat mom now.

key_stories.title: Creating the Toilet Paper Roll Mushroom
key_stories.summary: To fill an empty area in the craft-themed level, Kaze designed a new platforming element from scratch. Inspired by real-world crafts, he created a mushroom made from a toilet paper roll and gift wrap, complete with a custom model, texture, and shader to achieve a realistic look on the N64.
key_stories.challenge: A large, open level felt empty and needed unique, on-theme platforming elements to fill the space and guide the player.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed ideas with his chat and was inspired by real-world crafts. He decided to create a mushroom from a toilet paper roll and gift wrap, adding a staple for a 'rough' look. This involved modeling, sourcing and editing a texture, and programming a custom shader to achieve a convincing reflective effect on the N64.
key_stories.outcome: A new, thematically consistent platform was created from scratch, complete with a custom model, a user-provided texture, and a custom shader for a realistic shine. This asset helps define the level's unique 'craft world' aesthetic.
key_stories.key_quote: Dude, the toilet paper roll is too good. I can't not do this. But I'm just not sure on the stapler needle. Is the stapler needle too much? I think the stapler needle might be too rough.

key_stories.title: Diagnosing Performance on N64 Hardware
key_stories.summary: When the new level ran poorly on an actual N64, Kaze used a development cartridge to profile its performance in real-time. He diagnosed the issue as excessive 'overdraw' for the N64's renderer, not an excessive polygon count, providing a clear technical path to fixing the lag by optimizing geometry.
key_stories.challenge: The new, complex level was experiencing performance issues on real N64 hardware, and the cause needed to be identified and addressed.
key_stories.process: Kaze loaded the level onto an N64 via his Summer Cart and used a built-in profiler. By comparing the RSP and RDP timings, he determined the renderer (RDP) was struggling to draw overlapping polygons, a classic N64 issue. He also received a valuable code optimization tip from a viewer during the stream.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully diagnosed the performance bottleneck as RDP overdraw, not polygon count. This gives him a clear path forward for optimization, which involves carefully cutting unseen geometry rather than simply reducing model detail. He also identified and planned further low-level code optimizations.
key_stories.key_quote: Yeah, you can see 18 milliseconds RSP. So the RSP could run this at like 50 FPS and the RDP is at 36.8. That means it's all the overdraw.

open_questions.context: Kaze is shown performing all development tasks (design, modeling, coding). Other core team members like Biobak (art) and Badub (music) are known to be on the project but their contributions and workflow were not mentioned.
questions: How does the asset pipeline work between you, Biobak, and Badub?
What is the process for requesting and integrating new art or music into the game?
How are creative tasks delegated and reviewed among the core team?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions his spouse, Zeina, is an animator on the team and jokingly assigns her the role of 'chat mom'. Her specific contributions and their professional dynamic were not detailed.
questions: How do you and Zeina collaborate on the project as both partners and co-developers?
What has Zeina's role as an animator entailed for this project so far?
How does her feedback influence design decisions?

open_questions.context: Kaze briefly mentioned a specific objective involving a 'Luigi Doodle' where the player has to 'draw a star for him' to get a star in return. The mechanics of this interaction were not explained.
questions: Can you explain the gameplay mechanic behind the 'Luigi Doodle' objective?
How will the player physically 'draw a star' in-game?
What was the inspiration for this particular character and task?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions he is self-employed and references a specific, unusual payment situation involving $3,500 that he couldn't invoice due to missing information.
questions: You mentioned you're self-employed. How do you manage the financial side of a long-term, non-commercial project like this?
Are other key contributors compensated for their work on the project?
What is the business or financial structure that allows the project to continue?
